title-group.article-title: The Effect of Pneumococcal Polysaccharide Vaccine in a Mouse Model of Allergic Rhinitis

author-notes.corresp: Soo Whan Kim, MD, PhD, Department of Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery, College of Medicine, The Catholic University of Korea, 505 Banpo-dong, Seocho-gu, Seoul, 137-701, Korea Email: kshent@catholic.ac.kr

permissions.copyright-statement: © American Academy of Otolaryngology—Head and Neck Surgery Foundation 2013
permissions.copyright-holder: Official journal of the American Academy of Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery Foundation

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: This study aimed to determine if pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV) could suppress allergic inflammation in an allergic rhinitis mouse model and to explore whether differences exist regarding the effect of PPV according to timing of administration.

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: In vivo study using an animal model.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: Catholic Research Institutes of Medical Science.

sec.title: Subjects and Methods
sec.p: BALB/c mice were divided into control, Der f, Pre-S, and Post-S groups. The allergen was Dermatophagoides farinae (Der f). Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine was administered before (Pre-S) or after (Post-S) sensitization. Allergic symptoms and eosinophils in nasal mucosa, interferon-γ, interleukin (IL)–13, and IL-10 in nasal lavage fluid and serum Der f–specific IgE were measured. T-bet, GATA-3, and Foxp3 mRNA in spleen were determined by real-time polymerase chain reaction. Flow cytometry of CD4+CD25+Foxp3+ T cells in spleen was analyzed.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In the Pre-S group, symptom score, serum Der f–specific IgE, eosinophils, IL-13, and GATA-3 mRNA were decreased (P < .05), and IL-10, Foxp3 mRNA, and CD4+CD25+Foxp3+ T cells were increased compared with those in Der f group (P < .05). In the Post-S group, symptom score, serum Der f–specific IgE, and GATA-3 mRNA were decreased (P < .05), and Foxp3 mRNA and CD4+CD25+Foxp3+ T cells were increased compared with those in the Der f group (P < .05).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: These results suggest that PPV administered before or after sensitization suppresses Th2 response and enhanced induction of regulatory T cells in an allergic rhinitis model. In addition, there was no significant difference between the degrees of effects in these 2 conditions. In the future, we can consider PPV to be a preventative agent for allergic rhinitis.

body.p: Allergic rhinitis is an immunologic disorder by allergen-specific IgE in response to environmental exposures. Allergic rhinitis occurs in more than 500 million people worldwide, and its prevalence has shown a rapid increase, particularly in developed countries.1 This tendency could be explained by the “hygiene hypothesis” that better hygiene, resulting in decreased microbial exposure, leads to an increase in allergic disease.2

Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common respiratory pathogen and is a principal cause of otitis media, bacteremia, and meningitis.3,4 Streptococcus pneumoniae colonized in the hypopharyngeal region of neonates increases the risk of asthma early in life.5,6 Conversely, Talbot et al7 reported that asthma was associated with a doubled risk of pneumococcal infection.

The pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV) and pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) were developed to reduce the burden of pneumococcal diseases. Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine is approved for prevention of invasive pneumococcal disease in adults, and PCV was added to the routine childhood immunization schedule in the United States.8,9

Several studies have demonstrated the effect of S pneumoniae on allergic airway inflammation in experimental animal models. Killed S pneumoniae attenuated T-cell cytokine production, goblet cell hyperplasia, airway hyperresponsiveness, and tissue eosinophilia.10 Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine suppressed development of the allergic airway by inducing regulatory T (Treg) cells.11

The purpose of the present study was to investigate the effect of PPV on allergic inflammation and induction of Treg cells in a mouse model of allergic rhinitis. We also aimed to explore whether differences exist regarding the effect of PPV according to the timing of its administration. To know this, we compared the effects of PPV before sensitization with those of PPV after sensitization. Interferon (IFN)–γ and T-bet mRNA expression for Th1 responses were measured. Allergic symptoms, eosinophil counts in nasal mucosa, interleukin (IL)–13, serum Dermatophagoides farinae (Der f)–specific IgE levels, and GATA-3 mRNA expression were evaluated to know Th2 responses. Interleukin-10, Foxp3 mRNA expression, and the proportions of CD4+CD25+Foxp3+ T cells in spleen, markers of Treg cells, were also examined.

To our knowledge, this is the first study to evaluate the efficacy of topical PPV treatment in a mouse model of allergic rhinitis. In addition, an important strength of the current study is the use of Dermatophagoides farinae, which is a common allergen associated with allergic airway disease in patients.

sec.title: Experimental Animals
sec.p: Six-week-old female BALB/c mice (weight 20-30 g; Orient Bio, Seoul, Korea) were used in this study. The experiment was performed with the approval of the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee at the Catholic University of Korea.

sec.title: Reagents
sec.p: Der f crude body extract (Arthropods of Medical Importance Resource Bank, College of Medicine, Yonsei University, Seoul, Korea) was used as the allergen, which was lyophilized and stored at −70°C and dissolved before use. The pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (Pneumovax 23; Merck Sharp & Dohme Corp, West Point, Pennsylvania) was prepared in sterile phosphate-buffered saline (PBS).

sec.title: Allergic Rhinitis Model and Treatment Protocol
sec.p: As we had no a priori knowledge of the expected outcome in numerical value, no statistical sample size determination was performed. To determine the sample size in this study, we referred to the previous studies.12,13 Forty mice were randomized to 1 of 4 groups with 10 animals each: control, Der f (allergic rhinitis), Pre-S (administration of PPV before sensitization), and Post-S (administration of PPV after sensitization). Allergen sensitization and challenge are summarized in Figure 1. Briefly, on days 2 and 9, all mice except those in the control group were immunized with an intraperitoneal injection of 100 µg Der f. Mice in the Pre-S group were treated intranasally with 33 µg PPV on days 0, 0.5, 1, and 2, whereas mice in the Post-S group were treated on days 14, 14.5, 15, and 16. One week after sensitization, all sensitized mice were challenged intranasally with 20 µg Der f for 7 consecutive days. The control group received PBS intranasally instead of Der f.

caption.p: Schematic representation of the experimental allergic rhinitis model and treatment protocol. Al(OH)3, aluminum hydroxide; Der f, Dermatophagoides farinae; IN and in, intranasal administration; ip, intraperitoneal administration; PPV, pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine; Pre-S, administration of PPV before sensitization; Post-S, administration of PPV after sensitization.

sec.title: Allergic Symptoms
sec.p: The number of sneezing and nose-rubbing motions during 15 minutes after the final allergen challenge was recorded and compared among the experimental groups for 15 minutes. The assessors were blinded to the protocol.

sec.title: Nasal Lavage Fluid
sec.p: Using ether anesthesia, thoracotomy was performed on the mice 24 hours after the final allergen challenge. Nasal lavage fluid (NALF) was obtained after partial tracheal resection using 22-gauge catheters. The catheter was inserted into the tracheal opening in the direction of the upper airway into the nasopharynx. The nasal passages were perfused with 1 mL PBS from the choana to the nostril, and NALF was collected from the nares.

sec.title: Nasal Mucosa Tissue Evaluation
sec.p: The decapitated heads were fixed in paraformaldehyde, decalcified with Calci-Clear Rapid (National Diagnostics, Atlanta, Georgia), and embedded in paraffin blocks. The blocks were sliced into 4-µm-thick sections and stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) to evaluate general morphology and number of eosinophils in the lamina propria. The average number of eosinophils was counted in 4 areas around the nasal septa under a light microscope. The individual who counted the eosinophils was blinded to the protocol.

sec.title: Cytokines in NALF and Der f–Specific IgE Levels in Serum
sec.p: To evaluate the allergic reaction with NALF (supernatant from each group), interferon-γ for the Th1 immune reaction and IL-13 for the Th2 immune reaction were measured by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA; Multiplex; Millipore, Billerica, Massachusetts). In addition, IL-10 was measured using the Multiplex ELISA kit. The serum Der f–specific IgE level was measured using an ELISA kit (INDOOR Biotechnologies, Manchester, UK).

sec.title: Real-Time Polymerase Chain Reaction
sec.p: Spleens were removed aseptically 24 hours after the final challenge. Total RNA was extracted using TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, California) from splenic mononuclear cells, and the first strand was reverse-transcribed using a random primer (TaKaRa, Otsu, Japan). The oligonucleotide primer sequences were as follows: T-bet forward primer, 5′-GCCAGGGAACCGCTTATA-3′ and T-bet reverse primer, 5′-CCTTGTTGTTGGTGAGCTTTA-3′; GATA-3 forward primer, 5′-CTGGATGGCGGCAAAGC-3′ and GATA-3 reverse primer, 5′-GTGGGCGGGAAGGTGAA-3′; Foxp3 forward primer, 5′-GAAAGCGGATACCAAATGA-3′ and Foxp3 reverse primer, 5′-CTGTGAGGACTACCGAGCC-3′; and β-actin forward primer, 5′-CCCATCTACGAGGGCTAT-3′ and β-actin reverse primer, 5′-CCCATCTACGAGGGCTAT-3′. The expression levels of T-bet, GATA-3, Foxp3, and β-actin mRNA were determined by real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) using the ABI PRISM 7300 Real-Time PCR System (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, California) and SYBR Green PCR master mix (TaKaRa). The levels of expression of these mRNAs were analyzed using the ABI 7300 Sequence Detection System (Applied Biosystems). The results were normalized to β-actin expression and are shown as the fold increase over the expression of the control group.

sec.title: Flow Cytometry
sec.p: For cell surface staining, 106 splenic mononuclear cells were incubated with fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC)–conjugated mouse CD4 (GK1.5) antibody (eBioscience, San Diego, California). For intracellular staining, cells stained with CD4 were incubated with fixation/permeabilization working solution, and Fc receptors were blocked with excess mouse Fc block. Cells were then stained with phycoerythrin (PE)–Cy5-conjugated mouse Foxp3 (FJK-16s) and APC-CD25 antibodies (eBioscience). CD4+CD25+Foxp3+T cells were analyzed using FACS-Calibur (Becton Dickinson, San Jose, California).

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: All measured parameters are expressed as means ± standard deviations. The differences among the groups were analyzed using Kruskal-Wallis analysis. If statistical significances were found, the ranked parameters were compared using 1-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) and Bonferroni’s multiple-comparison tests (PASW Statistics 18; SPSS, Inc, an IBM Company, Chicago, Illinois). A value of P < .05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Allergic Symptoms
sec.p: The number of sneezes was 6.0 ± 1.6 in the control group, 38.7 ± 7.4 in the Der f group, 22.3 ± 6.4 in the Pre-S group, and 16.2 ± 6.9 in the Post-S group. The number of sneezes in the Der f group was elevated compared with that in all the other groups (vs control, P = .000; vs Pre-S, P = .000; vs Post-S, P = .000). In the control group, the number of sneezes was decreased compared with that in all the other groups (vs Der f; P = .000, vs Pre-S; P = .000, vs Post-S; P = .018). Other comparisons did not show significant differences.

The number of nasal rubbings was 6.1 ± 1.9 in the control group, 106.8 ± 33.9 in the Der f group, 55.5 ± 23.0 in the Pre-S group, and 36.4 ± 13.8 in the Post-S group. The number of nasal rubbings in the Der f group was elevated compared with that in all the other groups (vs control, P = .000; vs Pre-S, P = .003; vs Post-S, P = .000). In the control group, the number of nasal rubbings was decreased compared with that in all the other groups (vs Der f, P = .000; vs Pre-S, P = .000; vs Post-S, P = .015). Other comparisons did not show significant differences (Figure 2).

caption.p: Nasal symptom scores. The number of sneezes (A) and rubbing motions (B). Error bars represent standard deviations (SD). **P < .05 vs the control group; *P < .05 vs the Dermatophagoides farinae (Der f) group. Pre-S, administration of pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV) before sensitization; Post-S, administration of PPV after sensitization.

sec.title: Serum Der f–Specific IgE levels
sec.p: Serum Der f–specific IgE were elevated in the Der f group (9.9 ± 1.4 ng/mL) compared with those in the control group (0.4 ± 0.3 ng/mL, P = .000), Pre-S group (1.9 ± 1.0 ng/mL, P = .000), and Post-S group (5.2 ± 0.6 ng/mL, P = .000). In the control group, serum Der f–specific IgE decreased compared with those in all other groups (vs Der f, P = .000; vs Pre-S, P = .000; vs Post-S, P = .000). The Pre-S group showed lower serum Der f–specific IgE than the Post-S group (P = .018). There was no significance in comparison between other groups (Figure 3).

caption.p: Serum Dermatophagoides farinae (Der f)–specific IgE level. Error bars represent SD. *P < .05. Pre-S, administration of pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV) before sensitization; Post-S, administration of PPV after sensitization.

sec.title: Eosinophil Counts in the Lamina Propria
sec.p: Figure 4 shows the infiltration of eosinophils in the lamina propria. The number of eosinophils was 0.3 ± 0.2 in the control group, 94.2 ± 9.1 in the Der f group, 50.0 ± 11.4 in the Pre-S group, and 66.6 ± 7.1 in the Post-S group. The Der f group showed a higher eosinophil count than the control group (P = .000) or the Pre-S group (P = .000). The eosinophil count in the control group was lower than that in all other groups (vs Der f, P = .000; vs Pre-S, P = .002; vs Post-S, P = .000). These results show that PPV before sensitization can inhibit eosinophil infiltration in nasal mucosa. There was no significance in comparison between other groups (Figure 5).

caption.p: Infiltration of eosinophils (arrows) in the nasal mucosa of BALB/c mice. (A) Control group, (B) Dermatophagoides farinae (Der f) group, (C) Pre-S group, and (D) Post-S group. Hematoxylin and eosin stain; original magnification, ×400. Pre-S, administration of pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV) before sensitization; Post-S, administration of PPV after sensitization.

Eosinophil counts in the nasal mucosa of each study group. Error bars represent SD. *P < .05 vs the Dermatophagoides farinae (Der f) group. **P < .05 vs the control group. Pre-S, administration of pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV) before sensitization; Post-S, administration of PPV after sensitization.

sec.title: Cytokine Analysis of NALF
sec.p: Interferon-γ levels were 0.6 ± 0.2 pg/mL in the control group, 0.7 ± 0.3 pg/mL in the Der f group, 1.4 ± 0.9 pg/mL in the Pre-S group, and 0.7 ± 0.4 pg/mL in the Post-S group. No significant differences were observed among the groups (Figure 6A).

caption.p: Cytokine levels in the nasal lavage fluid of each study group: (A) interferon (IFN)–γ, (B) interleukin (IL)–13, and (C) IL-10. Error bars represent SD. *P < .05 vs the Dermatophagoides farinae (Der f) group. **P < .05 vs the control group. Pre-S, administration of pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV) before sensitization; Post-S, administration of PPV after sensitization.

sec.p: Interleukin-13 levels were 24.9 ± 4.76 pg/mL in the control group, 121.2 ± 63.0 pg/mL in the Der f group, 75.9 ± 34.4 pg/mL in the Pre-S group, and 71.8 ± 19.1 pg/mL in the Post-S group. Interleukin-13 in the Der f group was higher than that in the other groups (vs control, P = .002; vs Pre-S, P = .049; vs Post-S, P = .048). In the control group, IL-13 was lower than that in all other groups (vs Der f, P = .002; vs Pre-S, P = .018; vs Post-S, P = .05). These results indicate that PPV before and after sensitization decreased production of IL-13, a cytokine of the Th2 response. Other comparisons did not show significant differences (Figure 6B).

Interleukin-10 levels were 3.8 ± 1.3 pg/mL in the control group, 7.0 ± 6.4 pg/mL in the Der f group, 43.5 ± 42.0 pg/mL in the Pre-S group, and 16.0 ± 4.4 pg/mL in the Post-S group. Interleukin-10 increased in the Pre-S group compared with that in the control group (P = .014) and the Der f group (P = .018). There was no significance in comparison between other groups (Figure 6C).

sec.title: Real-Time PCR Analysis
sec.p: Comparisons of T-bet mRNA expression among the groups showed no statistical significances.

GATA-3 mRNA expression in the Der f group increased markedly compared with that in the control group (P = .000) and the Pre-S group (P = .049). The control group showed a lower GATA-3 mRNA expression than all other groups (vs Der f; P = .000; vs Pre-S, P = .014; vs Post-S, P = .000).

Foxp3 mRNA expression in the Pre-S group was elevated compared with that in the control group (P = .001) and Der f group (P = .005). In addition, in the Post-S group, Foxp3 mRNA expression was higher compared with that in the control group (P = .049) and Der f group (P = .01). There was no significance in comparison between other groups (Figure 7).

caption.p: Quantitative analysis of T-bet, GATA, and Foxp3 mRNA expression in splenic mononuclear cells by real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR). The results were normalized to β-actin expression. Error bars represent SD. *P < .05 vs the Dermatophagoides farinae (Der f) group. **P < .05 vs the control group. Pre-S, administration of pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV) before sensitization; Post-S, administration of PPV after sensitization.

sec.p: These results demonstrated that PPV administration before sensitization suppressed induction of Th2 cells and enhanced induction of Treg cells. Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine administration after sensitization also increased induction of Treg cells.

sec.title: Flow Cytometry of CD4+CD25+Foxp3+ T Cells
sec.p: Cells were sorted based on their level of Foxp3 and CD25 expression and whether they expressed CD4 (Figure 8A). The percentages of CD4+ CD25+Foxp3+ T cells as a proportion of total splenic mononuclear cells were 4.0% ± 0.6% in the control group, 1.6% ± 0.5% in the Der f group, 12.8% ± 5.0% in the Pre-S group, and 8.5% ± 5.5% in the Post-S group. The Pre-S group (P = .01) and the Post-S group (P = .039) had higher percentages of these cells than the control group. The percentage of these cells in the Der f group was decreased compared with those in the other groups (vs control, P = .049; vs Pre-S, P = .000; vs Post-S, P = .001). These results indicate that PPV increased induction of CD4+CD25+Foxp3+ T cells both before and after sensitization. There was no significance in comparison between other groups (Figure 8B).

caption.p: Flow cytometric analysis of CD4+CD25+Foxp3+ T cell subsets. (A) Representative fluorescence-activated cell sorting analysis of each group. The upper right quadrant represents CD4+CD25+Foxp3+ T cells. (B) The percentages of CD4+CD25+Foxp3+ T cells as a proportion of total splenic mononuclear cells. RU, upper right quadrant, representing CD4+CD25+Foxp3+ T cells. Error bars represent SD. P < .05 vs the Dermatophagoides farinae (Der f) group. **P < .05 vs the control group. Pre-S, administration of pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV) before sensitization; Post-S, administration of PPV after sensitization.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Streptococcus pneumoniae causes respiratory infections worldwide. Because PCV was added to the routine childhood immunization schedule in the United States, the incidence of invasive pneumococcal disease has declined by 60% to 90% in children younger than 2 years.8

Several studies have been reported regarding the association between allergic diseases and pneumococcal infection. Klemets et al14 suggested that working-age adults with asthma were at an increased risk of invasive pneumococcal infections and pneumococcal vaccination might be needed for these patients. Atopic dermatitis and allergic rhinitis are also associated with an increased risk of serious pneumococcal diseases.15 In experimental studies, pneumococcal infection reduced circulating eosinophils.16

Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine includes 23 capsular polysaccharide antigens (serotypes 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6B, 7F, 8, 9N, 9V, 10A, 11A, 12F, 14, 15B, 17F, 18C, 19A, 19F, 20, 22F, 23F, and 33F) and induces a persistent functional antibody response in adults. However, PPVs are generally not considered to be immunogenic in children younger than 2 years and are recommended for children older than 24 months of age who are at high risk for invasive pneumococcal infection.17,18 A retrospective cohort study reported a decrease in the risk of hospital admission for asthma in vaccinated compared with nonvaccinated subjects.19 However, the Cochrane review of PPV in 2002 concluded that the effect of pneumococcal vaccine on asthma was limited.20

Several experimental studies evaluated the effect of S pneumoniae on allergic airway disease using killed bacteria or pneumococcal vaccines. Both whole-killed S pneumoniae and PCV suppressed allergic inflammation and development of allergic airway disease by inducing Treg cells.10,11,21 A recent study reported that S pneumonia component-induced Treg cells suppressed the activity of natural killer T cells and allergic airway disease.22

We aimed to reveal whether PPV treatment reduces allergic inflammation in an allergic rhinitis model and to elucidate the mechanisms. In particular, we used Der f, a common allergen in patients, to develop an allergic model. In the Pre-S group, the allergic symptom score, serum Der f–specific IgE, tissue eosinophil counts, IL-13 levels, and GATA-3 mRNA were decreased compared with those in the Der f group. In addition, IL-10 levels, Foxp3 mRNA levels, and the percentages of CD4+CD25+Foxp3+ T cells in the Pre-S group were increased compared with those in the Der f group. However, comparisons of IFN-γ levels and T-bet mRNA expression levels among the groups showed no significances. From these results, we concluded that PPV treatment before sensitization suppresses Th2 responses and enhances induction of Treg cells. However, these results were different from a previous study that demonstrated that PPV failed to suppress allergic inflammation.11 This discrepancy may be caused by differences in the timing of PPV administration, the number of PPV administrations, the protocol for induction of allergic inflammation (the schedule of allergen sensitization and challenge), and exposed allergens (Der f vs ovalbumin).

We also explored whether differences exist concerning the effect of PPV according to the timing of its administration. In the Post-S group, the allergic symptom score, serum Der f–specific IgE, and GATA-3 mRNA expression were decreased compared with those in the Der f group. In addition, Foxp3 mRNA expression and CD4+CD25+Foxp3+ T cells in the Post-S group were increased compared with those in the Der f group. However, there were no significant differences between 2 groups. Therefore, we suggested that there is equal benefit irrespective of whether the PPV treatment is given before or after sensitization.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The present study suggests that PPV administered before or after allergen sensitization effectively suppressed the allergen-specific Th2 response and enhanced induction of Treg cells in a model of allergic rhinitis. In addition, there was no significant difference between the degrees of effects in these 2 conditions. Further studies are needed regarding PPV; however, in the future, we can consider PPV to be a preventative agent in the treatment of allergic rhinitis.

sec.title: Author Contributions
sec.p: Ji-Hyeon Shin, designed study, analyzed data, wrote article; Boo Young Kim, designed study, analyzed data, wrote article; Hyang Rim Park, collected data, analyzed data; Sung Won Kim, analyzed data; Soo Whan Kim, collected data, revised article.

sec.title: Disclosures
sec.p: Competing interests: None.
Sponsorships: None.
Funding source: Basic Science Research Program through the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF), funded by the Ministry of Education, Science, and Technology (2011-0026915).

fn.p: Sponsorships or competing interests that may be relevant to content are disclosed at the end of this article.
Presented at the meeting of the European Academy of Allergy and Clinical Immunology (EAACI) Congress; June 19, 2012; Geneva, Switzerland.
